name: Barbell Bent-Over Row Overhand Grip
description: A fundamental compound pulling movement performed with an overhand (pronated) grip that targets the entire back musculature with emphasis on the upper back and rear deltoids. The overhand grip promotes greater lat stretch and recruits more upper back muscles compared to underhand variations.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip barbell slightly wider than shoulder width with overhand grip
Hinge at hips until torso is roughly 45-60 degrees to the floor, maintaining flat back
Let arms hang straight down with slight elbow bend, bar positioned below shoulders
Pull barbell toward lower chest/upper abdomen, driving elbows back and squeezing shoulder blades
Lower bar under control to starting position, maintaining hip hinge throughout

name: Barbell Bent-Over Row Underhand Grip
description: A bent-over row variation using a supinated (underhand) grip that increases bicep recruitment and allows for greater lat stretch at the bottom. This grip typically allows pulling to a lower position on the torso, emphasizing the lower lats.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip barbell shoulder-width with underhand grip
Hinge forward at hips until torso is 45-60 degrees to floor with flat back
Let bar hang with arms fully extended below shoulders
Pull bar toward lower abdomen, keeping elbows close to body
Squeeze lats hard at top, lower under control to full stretch
formCues: Keep elbows tucked close to sides
Focus on lat squeeze at top

name: Pendlay Row
description: An explosive barbell row variation named after weightlifting coach Glenn Pendlay, performed with the torso parallel to the floor and bar returning to the ground each rep. This dead-stop technique eliminates momentum and builds explosive pulling power.
instructions: Set up with barbell on floor, feet hip-width, using overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder width
Hinge until torso is completely parallel to floor, back flat
Pull bar explosively from floor to lower chest in one powerful motion
Lower bar back to floor under control, coming to complete stop
Reset position and repeat, each rep starting from dead stop
formCues: Torso must be parallel to floor
commonMistakes: Bouncing bar instead of dead stop

name: Single-Arm Dumbbell Row
description: A unilateral rowing movement performed with one arm at a time, typically with the non-working hand braced on a bench. This exercise allows for greater range of motion, helps correct muscle imbalances, and reduces lower back stress.
instructions: Place one knee and same-side hand on bench, opposite foot on floor for stability
Hold dumbbell in free hand with arm fully extended toward floor
Keep back flat and parallel to floor, core braced
Row dumbbell to hip by driving elbow toward ceiling
Lower under control to full stretch, complete all reps then switch sides
formCues: Keep core engaged to prevent rotation
commonMistakes: Not using full range of motion
Rowing to chest instead of hip

name: Chest-Supported Dumbbell Row
description: A rowing variation performed lying face-down on an incline bench, completely eliminating lower back involvement and momentum. This strict isolation allows for maximum lat and upper back focus with zero cheating potential.
instructions: Set incline bench to 30-45 degrees and lie face down with chest on pad
Let arms hang straight down holding dumbbells with neutral or pronated grip
Plant feet firmly on floor for stability
Row both dumbbells simultaneously toward hips, squeezing shoulder blades
Lower under control to full extension, feeling lat stretch
commonMistakes: Not using full range of motion

name: Seated Cable Row
description: A staple horizontal pulling exercise using a cable machine that provides constant tension throughout the entire range of motion. The seated position and cable resistance create an ideal environment for targeting the middle back and lats.
instructions: Sit on cable row station with feet on footplates, knees slightly bent
Grasp V-bar or straight bar attachment with arms extended
Sit upright with slight forward lean, chest up and shoulders back
Pull handle toward lower abdomen, driving elbows back past torso
Squeeze shoulder blades together at contraction, return to start with control

name: Standing Cable Row
description: A functional rowing variation performed standing that engages more core and posterior chain muscles for stability. The standing position allows for natural hip hinge integration and translates well to athletic movements.
instructions: Set cable at chest height, stand facing machine in athletic stance
Grasp handle with both hands, step back until cable is taut
Hinge slightly at hips with soft knees, brace core
Pull handle toward lower chest/upper abdomen driving elbows back
Squeeze back muscles at contraction, extend arms with control

name: Single-Arm Cable Row
description: A unilateral cable rowing movement that allows for greater range of motion, rotational work, and muscle imbalance correction. The single-arm approach increases core anti-rotation demands while providing excellent lat isolation.
instructions: Set cable at mid-torso height, stand in staggered stance facing machine
Grasp D-handle with one hand, step back until cable is taut
Brace core to resist rotation, maintain upright torso
Row handle toward hip, driving elbow back and rotating slightly
Control the return to full stretch, complete all reps then switch sides
formCues: Allow slight torso rotation at peak
Equal reps and weight both sides

name: T-Bar Row
description: A classic back builder performed using a T-bar apparatus or landmine setup that allows for heavy loading with a neutral grip. The fixed pivot point provides stability while enabling aggressive pulling through the mid and lower back.
instructions: Straddle the T-bar with feet wider than shoulder width for stability
Grasp handles with neutral grip, hinge forward with flat back
Let weight hang with arms extended, torso at 45-60 degrees
Row bar toward chest by driving elbows up and back
Squeeze back at top, lower under control to full stretch

name: Machine Row
description: A guided rowing movement performed on a chest-supported or plate-loaded row machine that isolates the back muscles with minimal technique requirements. The fixed path makes it ideal for beginners or high-intensity techniques like drop sets.
instructions: Adjust seat height so handles align with lower chest when arms extended
Sit with chest against pad (if present), feet firmly planted
Grasp handles with chosen grip, arms fully extended
Pull handles toward body, squeezing shoulder blades together
Control the return to starting position without letting weight stack crash
formCues: Keep chest against pad if present

name: Inverted Row
description: A bodyweight horizontal pulling exercise performed by hanging underneath a bar and rowing your chest toward it. This scalable movement builds pulling strength and serves as an excellent progression toward pull-ups while being gentler on joints.
instructions: Set barbell in rack at waist height or use suspension trainer
Grip bar slightly wider than shoulders, hang underneath with body straight
Keep heels on ground, body rigid from head to heels
Pull chest toward bar by driving elbows back and squeezing shoulder blades
Lower under control to full arm extension
formCues: Keep body rigid like a plank
Touch chest to bar each rep

name: Meadows Row
description: A unique single-arm landmine row variation created by John Meadows that emphasizes a long range of motion and intense lat stretch. The perpendicular stance and overhand grip create a distinctive pulling angle that targets the lats differently.
instructions: Set barbell in landmine attachment, stand perpendicular to bar end
Stagger stance with inside leg forward, hinge at hips
Grip bar end with overhand grip, outside arm on thigh for support
Row bar toward hip in an arc, driving elbow high and back
Lower to full stretch, feeling deep lat engagement at bottom
commonMistakes: Not using full range of motion
Rowing straight up instead of arc

name: Helms Row
description: A chest-supported dumbbell row variation developed by Eric Helms where both feet are planted on the floor behind the bench. This position allows for heavier loading while maintaining strict form and minimizing lower back stress.
instructions: Set incline bench to 30-45 degrees, stand behind it
Place chest on top of bench pad, feet flat on floor behind you
Hold dumbbells with arms hanging straight down
Row both dumbbells to hips, driving elbows back and up
Squeeze back at top, lower to full stretch with control
formCues: Can go heavier than standard chest-supported

name: Resistance Band Row
description: A versatile horizontal pulling movement using resistance bands that provides accommodating resistance and joint-friendly training. The band's variable resistance increases tension at peak contraction, making it excellent for home workouts.
instructions: Anchor band at chest height or sit with band looped around feet
Grasp band handles or ends with arms extended toward anchor
Sit tall or stand in athletic position with core braced
Pull hands toward torso, driving elbows back past body
Squeeze shoulder blades together at peak, control return to start

name: Standard Pull-Up
description: The gold standard vertical pulling exercise using bodyweight with an overhand (pronated) grip slightly wider than shoulder width. This fundamental movement builds lat width, grip strength, and overall upper body pulling power.
instructions: Hang from pull-up bar with overhand grip, hands slightly wider than shoulders
Start from dead hang with arms fully extended and shoulders engaged
Pull body up by driving elbows down and back toward hips
Continue until chin clears the bar or chest touches
Lower under control to full dead hang, repeat
commonMistakes: Not using full range of motion

name: Wide-Grip Pull-Up
description: A pull-up variation with hands placed wider than shoulder width that emphasizes lat width and creates greater lat stretch at the bottom. The wider grip reduces bicep involvement and increases the challenge on the outer lats.
instructions: Grip pull-up bar approximately 1.5 times shoulder width with overhand grip
Hang with arms fully extended, shoulders engaged
Pull up by driving elbows down toward hips
Bring chin over bar or touch upper chest to bar
Lower with control to full dead hang
commonMistakes: Grip too wide causing shoulder strain

name: Close-Grip Pull-Up
description: A pull-up variation with hands placed closer together than shoulder width. This grip increases lower lat and bicep involvement while allowing for more reps than wide grip variations.
instructions: Grip bar with hands 6-12 inches apart using overhand or neutral grip
Hang with arms fully extended from dead hang
Pull up driving elbows down and toward your sides
Bring chin over bar at minimum, ideally touch chest
Lower with complete control to full extension
commonMistakes: Grip too close causing wrist strain

name: Chin-Up
description: A vertical pulling exercise using an underhand (supinated) grip that maximizes bicep involvement while still heavily targeting the lats. Generally easier than pull-ups for most people due to greater bicep contribution.
instructions: Grip bar with underhand grip at shoulder width or slightly narrower
Hang from dead hang with arms fully extended
Pull body up by driving elbows down and back toward ribs
Continue until chin clears bar, ideally upper chest touches
Lower with control to full dead hang
formCues: Squeeze biceps and lats at top
commonMistakes: Not using full range of motion

name: Neutral-Grip Pull-Up
description: A pull-up variation using parallel handles with palms facing each other, providing a shoulder-friendly option that balances lat and bicep activation. This grip is often the most comfortable for high-volume pulling work.
instructions: Grip parallel handles with palms facing each other
Hang from dead hang with arms fully extended
Pull body up driving elbows down toward hips
Continue until chin clears handles or chest touches
Lower with control to full extension

name: Wide-Grip Lat Pulldown
description: A cable machine exercise that mimics the pull-up motion with adjustable resistance, targeting lat width with a wide overhand grip. Ideal for beginners building toward pull-ups or advanced lifters seeking higher volume lat work.
instructions: Sit at lat pulldown machine with thighs secured under pads
Grip bar wider than shoulder width with overhand grip
Sit tall with slight backward lean, chest up
Pull bar down toward upper chest, driving elbows down and back
Squeeze lats at bottom, control bar back to full stretch

name: Close-Grip Lat Pulldown
description: A lat pulldown variation using a V-bar or close grip attachment that emphasizes the lower lats and allows for greater range of motion. The close grip also increases bicep involvement.
instructions: Attach V-bar handle to lat pulldown cable
Sit with thighs secured under pads, grip handle with both hands
Sit tall with slight backward lean, arms fully extended above
Pull handle down toward upper chest, driving elbows down and in
Squeeze lats at contraction, extend arms with control

name: Neutral-Grip Lat Pulldown
description: A shoulder-friendly lat pulldown variation using parallel handles with palms facing each other. This grip provides excellent lat activation with reduced shoulder stress.
instructions: Attach parallel grip handle to lat pulldown
Sit with thighs secured, grip handles with palms facing each other
Start with arms fully extended, chest up, slight lean back
Pull handles down toward chest, driving elbows down and back
Squeeze lats at bottom, extend arms with control to full stretch

name: Single-Arm Lat Pulldown
description: A unilateral lat pulldown variation that allows for greater range of motion and helps identify and correct strength imbalances. The single-arm approach creates additional core anti-rotation demands.
instructions: Attach single handle to lat pulldown cable
Sit or kneel beside machine, grip handle with one hand, arm extended overhead
Brace core to resist rotation throughout movement
Pull handle down toward shoulder, driving elbow down and back
Squeeze lat at contraction, extend arm with control, complete all reps then switch
formCues: Allow slight torso lean at bottom

name: Assisted Pull-Up
description: A regression of the standard pull-up using a machine, band, or spotter to reduce the load being lifted. This progression-building exercise allows beginners to develop pull-up strength with proper form.
instructions: Set assistance level on machine or secure band to pull-up bar
Step onto machine platform or place knee/foot in band loop
Grip bar with chosen grip, arms fully extended
Pull body up using both your strength and the assistance
Lower with control to full extension, repeat with consistent assistance
formCues: Use same form as full pull-up
Don't rely on assistance to initiate

name: Negative Pull-Up
description: An eccentric-focused pull-up progression where you jump or step to the top position and slowly lower yourself down. This technique builds the strength needed for full pull-ups by overloading the lowering phase.
instructions: Use step, box, or jump to get chin above the bar
Grip bar with chosen grip, body in top pull-up position
Remove feet from support, holding top position briefly
Lower body as slowly as possible for 3-5 seconds minimum
Step back up and repeat, focusing on maximum time under tension
commonMistakes: Not starting from true top position
Too many reps causing form breakdown

name: Archer Pull-Up
description: An advanced unilateral pull-up progression where one arm does the majority of the work while the other arm extends to the side for assistance. This bridges the gap between standard pull-ups and one-arm pull-ups.
instructions: Grip bar with wide overhand grip, wider than normal pull-ups
Hang from dead hang with arms fully extended
Pull toward one hand, extending the other arm out straight
Continue until chin passes the working hand
Lower with control, alternate sides or complete all reps per side

name: Conventional Deadlift
description: The king of posterior chain exercises, lifting a loaded barbell from the floor to hip height using a hip-dominant hinge pattern. This fundamental movement builds total body strength, particularly targeting the posterior chain, grip, and core.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, barbell over mid-foot
Hinge at hips and grip bar just outside legs with mixed or double overhand grip
Set back flat, chest up, shoulders over or slightly ahead of bar
Drive through floor, extending hips and knees simultaneously
Stand tall with hips fully extended, lower by hinging hips then bending knees
commonMistakes: Starting with hips too high or low

name: Romanian Deadlift
description: A hip hinge movement emphasizing the eccentric stretch of the hamstrings and maintaining constant tension throughout. Unlike conventional deadlifts, the bar doesn't touch the floor between reps.
instructions: Stand holding barbell at hip height with overhand grip, feet hip-width apart
Unlock knees slightly, maintaining this angle throughout
Push hips back while lowering bar along thighs and shins
Descend until hamstrings reach maximum stretch without back rounding
Drive hips forward to return to standing, squeezing glutes at top

name: Sumo Deadlift
description: A wide-stance deadlift variation with feet outside hands that reduces range of motion and shifts emphasis to the quads, adductors, and hips. Often preferred by lifters with longer torsos.
instructions: Stand with very wide stance, toes pointed out 30-45 degrees
Grip bar between legs at shoulder width or narrower
Squat down with upright torso, hips close to bar
Drive through legs while pulling bar straight up
Stand tall, squeeze glutes at lockout, lower with control

name: Trap Bar Deadlift
description: A deadlift variation using a hexagonal bar that allows neutral grip and centers the load around the body. This setup reduces lower back stress and is more accessible for beginners.
instructions: Stand inside trap bar with feet hip-width apart
Grip handles with neutral grip, arms straight
Squat down with flat back, chest up, shoulders back
Drive through floor, extending hips and knees together
Stand tall at top, lower with control by hinging then squatting

name: Single-Leg Romanian Deadlift
description: A unilateral hip hinge that challenges balance, stability, and single-leg strength while targeting the hamstrings and glutes. This exercise addresses muscle imbalances and develops proprioception.
instructions: Stand on one leg holding dumbbell or kettlebell in opposite hand
Hinge at hip, extending free leg behind for counterbalance
Lower weight toward floor while keeping hips square
Descend until hamstring fully stretched or torso parallel to floor
Drive hips forward to return to standing, complete all reps then switch

name: Good Morning
description: A barbell hip hinge exercise with the bar on the back, emphasizing hamstring and lower back strength through a bow-like movement. Builds posterior chain strength critical for squat and deadlift performance.
instructions: Position barbell on upper back as for back squat
Stand with feet hip to shoulder width apart, slight knee bend
Push hips back and hinge forward, keeping back flat
Lower until torso is parallel to floor or hamstrings fully stretched
Drive hips forward to return to standing position

name: Rack Pull
description: A partial range deadlift performed from blocks or safety pins set at or above knee height. This overload exercise allows for heavier weights than full deadlifts, building lockout strength and back thickness.
instructions: Set safety pins in rack at knee height or above
Stand at bar as for deadlift, feet hip-width apart
Grip bar with overhand or mixed grip, set back flat
Drive through legs and hips to lift bar to lockout
Lower bar to pins with control, reset for next rep

name: Deficit Deadlift
description: An advanced deadlift variation performed while standing on a raised platform, increasing range of motion and difficulty off the floor. Builds starting strength and addresses weaknesses in the initial pull phase.
instructions: Stand on 1-4 inch platform or plates, feet hip-width apart
Set up as for conventional deadlift with bar over mid-foot
Hinge down and grip bar, requiring deeper hip position than normal
Maintain flat back despite increased range of motion
Drive through floor, extending hips and knees to standing
formCues: Use lighter weight than regular deadlift

name: Straight-Arm Pulldown
description: An isolation exercise targeting the lats through shoulder extension with arms kept straight throughout. Provides constant tension on the lats without bicep involvement, excellent for mind-muscle connection.
instructions: Stand facing high cable pulley with straight bar or rope attachment
Grip bar with arms extended overhead at shoulder height
Maintain soft elbow lock throughout movement
Pull bar down in arc to hips by driving arms down
Squeeze lats at bottom, return with control to start

name: Face Pull
description: A cable exercise targeting the rear deltoids, rhomboids, and external rotators critical for shoulder health and posture. Counteracts forward shoulder posture from pressing exercises.
instructions: Set cable pulley at face height with rope attachment
Grip rope with overhand grip, step back until cable is taut
Start with arms extended toward pulley at face height
Pull rope toward face, separating hands and driving elbows high and back
Externally rotate at end, squeezing rear delts and upper back
formCues: Pull to face level, not chest

name: Dumbbell Reverse Fly
description: An isolation exercise targeting the rear deltoids and upper back muscles using dumbbells in a bent-over position. Essential for balanced shoulder development and postural health.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width, hinge forward to 45-60 degrees
Hold dumbbells hanging below with slight elbow bend, palms facing each other
Raise dumbbells out to sides in arc until arms are parallel to floor
Squeeze rear delts and upper back at top
Lower with control to starting position

name: Cable Reverse Fly
description: A rear deltoid isolation exercise using cables that provides constant tension throughout the movement. The cable resistance creates a unique strength curve compared to dumbbell variations.
instructions: Set cables at shoulder height, stand centered between two cable stacks
Cross cables grabbing opposite handles with no attachments
Start with arms crossed in front at shoulder height
Pull handles outward in arc, squeezing rear delts as arms separate
Control return to starting crossed position

name: Barbell Shrug
description: An isolation exercise targeting the upper trapezius muscles using a barbell. The heavy loading potential makes this ideal for building trap size and strength for improved posture and deadlift lockout.
instructions: Stand holding barbell at thigh level with overhand grip, shoulder width or slightly wider
Stand tall with shoulders down and back, arms straight
Elevate shoulders straight up toward ears as high as possible
Hold peak contraction for 1-2 seconds
Lower shoulders under control to starting position

name: Dumbbell Shrug
description: A trap isolation exercise using dumbbells that allows for a more natural arm position at the sides of the body. The independent loading helps correct any strength imbalances between sides.
instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at sides with neutral grip, palms facing body
Stand tall with shoulders down, arms straight
Elevate shoulders straight up as high as possible toward ears
Squeeze and hold at top for 1-2 seconds
Lower with control back to starting position
